title: Dailies Summaries
text:
Welcome
This book compiles summaries from all dailies throughout the semester. Use the sidebar navigation to view results from each daily.
Each daily summary includes:

title: Dailies Summaries
text:
Class Performance — Overall statistics (n, mean, median, SD, score range)
Score Distribution — Histogram of total scores
Performance by Question — Bar chart showing class performance on each question
Question Breakdowns (Q1–Q5) — Correct answers and common errors observed
Key Takeaways — Strengths and areas to review

title: Dailies Summaries
text:
How to Use This Resource
Review your daily feedback to:

Identify concepts that need more attention
Learn from common errors made by the class
Track your progress throughout the semester

title: Daily 1 - Jan 12
text:
Class Performance
Scores ranged from 0.5 to 4.5 out of 5 points.

title: Daily 1 - Jan 12
text: Students: 118 | Mean: 2.45 | Median: 2.5 | SD: 0.96

title: Daily 1 - Jan 12
text: Score Distribution

title: Daily 1 - Jan 12
text: Performance by Question

title: Daily 1 - Jan 12
text:
Questions

Q1: What does a histogram tell you?






Correct Answer





A histogram shows the frequency distribution of continuous data — how many observations fall within each range/bin.









Common Errors






Confusing with time series (“data over time”)
Confusing with bar charts (“comparing categories”)
Confusing with box plots (mentioning quartiles)







Q2: What does standard deviation measure?






Correct Answer





SD measures how spread out the data is from the mean — the average distance of data points from the center.









Common Errors






Confusing mean with median (“distance from the median”)
Confusing with residuals (“how far from predicted value”)
Confusing with IQR/range







Q3: What is a regression?






Correct Answer





A regression is a statistical model that describes the relationship between variables — how independent variable(s) predict a dependent variable.









Common Errors






Using everyday meaning (“decline” or “going backwards”)
Confusing with hypothesis testing
Confusing with correlation







Q4: How do you estimate a regression?






Correct Answer





Using Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) — finding coefficients that minimize the sum of squared residuals.









Common Errors






Naming tools instead of methods (“Excel,” “JMP”)
Circular answers (“regression analysis”)
High blank rate — most skipped question







Q5: How do you test significance of a coefficient?






Correct Answer





Compare the p-value to alpha (typically 0.05). If p-value < alpha, the coefficient is statistically significant.









Common Errors






Comparing coefficient to a number (“if coefficient > 1”)
Using R² instead of p-value
Just naming the test without explanation

title: Daily 1 - Jan 12
text:
Key Takeaways
Strengths: SD measures spread from mean | p-value vs alpha | Regression models relationships
Review:

Histograms show frequency distribution — not time series or bar charts
OLS minimizes squared residuals — naming software doesn’t explain it
p < alpha → significant — compare p-value to 0.05

title: Daily 2 - Jan 14
text:
Class Performance
Scores ranged from 3 to 3 out of 3 points.

title: Daily 2 - Jan 14
text: Students: 117 | Mean: 3.00 | Median: 3 | SD: 0.00

title: Daily 2 - Jan 14
text: Score Distribution

title: Daily 2 - Jan 14
text: Performance by Question

title: Daily 2 - Jan 14
text:
Questions

Q1: If I am cited for the unauthorized use of an electronic device, I (will/will not) _____ be permitted to submit the Daily for the day, resulting in a grade of _____ for that Daily.






Correct Answer





“will not” and “zero” (or “0”) — If cited for unauthorized electronic device use, you will not be permitted to submit the Daily, resulting in a grade of zero.









Common Errors





No common errors observed — All students correctly identified the policy from the syllabus.






Q2: Where did you create your BUSN 5000 folder?






Correct Answer





Desktop (or similar valid location like Documents, a specific drive, etc.)









Common Errors





No common errors observed — All students correctly identified where they created their course folder.






Q3: In R Studio, I can browse the files in my R project directory in the southeast pane under the _____ tab.






Correct Answer





Files — In RStudio, the Files tab in the southeast pane allows you to browse project directory files.









Common Errors





No common errors observed — All students correctly identified the Files tab for browsing project files.

title: Daily 2 - Jan 14
text:
Key Takeaways
Strengths: Excellent class performance! All students demonstrated clear understanding of course policies and RStudio basics.
Looking Ahead:

Continue building familiarity with RStudio interface
Remember the electronic device policy throughout the semester
Use the Files tab for navigating your project directories

title: Daily 3 - Jan 21
text:
Class Performance
Scores ranged from 1 to 4 out of 4 points.

title: Daily 3 - Jan 21
text: Students: 113 | Mean: 2.61 | Median: 2.5 | SD: 0.59

title: Daily 3 - Jan 21
text: Score Distribution

title: Daily 3 - Jan 21
text: Performance by Question

title: Daily 3 - Jan 21
text:
Questions

Q1: The .Rmd file extension signifies what type of file?






Correct Answer





R Markdown — a file format that combines text, code, and output in a single document.









Common Errors






Saying “R Script” — .R is an R Script file; .Rmd is R Markdown which adds documentation capabilities
Vague answers — “R file” or “data file” don’t capture the specific meaning of R Markdown
Confusing with CSV — CSV is a data format; .Rmd is a document format for reproducible analysis







Q2: What is the unit of record in the CPS?






Correct Answer





Person — each row in the CPS represents one individual person surveyed.









Common Errors






Answering “young men” — The dataset in class focused on young men, but the CPS unit of record is “person” — individual people of any demographic
Answering “labor force” — Labor force describes the population being studied, not the unit of observation
Answering “ID” or “key variable” — ID is a variable that identifies the person, but “person” is the unit itself







Q3: For data to be “tidy”, every entry or cell must correspond to a _____.






Correct Answer





Single value — each cell contains exactly one piece of data.









Common Errors






Missing “single” — Answering just “value” without specifying “single” misses the key constraint
Confusing with variable — Variables are columns; each cell contains a single value of that variable
Confusing with observation — Observations are rows; each cell is one value within an observation







Q4: The term ATAC captures four steps in the data value chain: Acquisition, _____, _____, and Communication.






Correct Answer





Transformation, Analysis — The full chain is Acquisition, Transformation, Analysis, Communication.









Common Errors






Misspelling “Translation” — The step is “Transformation” not “Translation”
Wrong order — Analysis comes after Transformation, before Communication

title: Daily 3 - Jan 21
text:
Key Takeaways
Strengths: R Markdown identification, ATAC framework, and tidy data concepts are emerging.
Review:

Unit of record = person — Don’t confuse with the specific subset (young men) used in class
Single value per cell — Include “single” when describing tidy data
ATAC = Acquisition, Transformation, Analysis, Communication — Memorize the sequence
